section.title: Introduction
section.para: PHP 5.3 has relatively recently been released, so you won't find it precompiled for some operating systems. Here we will describe they way to install it on three operating systems: Debian Linux (Lenny/Etch), MacOS and Windows (XP).

section.title: Installation on Debian Linux
section.para: At the moment there are no official packages for PHP5.3 available. Therefore you will have to adjust your packages sources as follows. You should not do this in your production environment, since you will overwrite your stable and tested PHP 5.2 packages!
Currently you can use the PHP 5.3 packages provided by dotdeb.org to install PHP 5.3 on Debian Lenny. To do that you have to edit your /etc/apt/sources.list and add these lines:

screen.code: # PHP 5.3 packages by dotdeb deb http://php53.dotdeb.org stable all deb-src http://php53.dotdeb.org stable all

section.para: As dotdeb doesn't provide packages for Debian Etch, netlogix backported the Lenny packages to Etch. Packages are available from ftp://ftp.hosting.netlogix.de/php5.3/debian/.
Open /etc/apt/sources.list in your favourite editor and add the following lines to the file:

para.screen: # PHP 5.3 packages backported by netlogix deb ftp://ftp.hosting.netlogix.de/php5.3/debian/ etch php deb-src ftp://ftp.hosting.netlogix.de/php5.3/debian/ etch php

section.para:
To install the packages you'll have to do the following:
Update the package cache:
aptitude update
If you already have PHP installed on your system, use the following command to update the installed version to PHP 5.3:
aptitude dist-upgrade
If you do not have PHP installed already, use this to install the necessary packages:
aptitude install apache2 php5 libapache2-mod-php5 php5-sqlite
This will install PHP 5.3, the Apache webserver and the necessary dependencies onto your system. You will be asked a question about installing untrusted packages onto your system. If you want to continue, say "yes".
Optional: If you want to use MySQL as persistence backend you'll also need to install the mysql-pdo driver:
aptitude install php5-mysql

para.bridgehead: Configuring and starting the apache webserver:

section.para: These are some recommended configuration options:

step.para: Enable the required apache modules:
Adjust the vhost to allow the FLOW3 .htaccess files to configure your environment. The vhost configuration files reside in /etc/apache2/sites-available/:
step.screen: <Directory /var/www/> Options Indexes FollowSymLinks MultiViews AllowOverride All # Make sure to set this directive correctly Order allow,deny allow from all # This directive allows us to have apache2's default start page # in /apache2-default/, but still have / go to the right place RedirectMatch ^/$ /apache2-default/ </Directory>

note.para: For a comfortable and secure environment the document root of apache's default webserver instance (or the vhost you are using) should be changed to the Web folder of FLOW3. To do that, make sure to change every use of /var/www to /var/www/<your FLOW3 directory>/Web in your vhost configuration.

section.title: Installation on MacOS
section.para: This part explains how to install PHP 5.3 using MacPorts. For this you need to have Xcode installed, you can download and install it from http://developer.apple.com/mac/ (you need a free ADC login for that). After you have Xcode installed, install MacPorts as described on http://www.macports.org/install.php#pkg. You might want to install Porticus from http://porticus.alittledrop.com/ which provides a nice user interface for installing and removing packages with MacPorts. For the next steps we'll assume you use a terminal session, though.

step.para: First of all install PHP 5.3 itself. Along with the port name some variants are specified, those enable additional functionality:

callout.para: This tells MacPorts to update itself and the information about available ports.
Install PHP 5.3 with Apache 2 support an PEAR.
Install the mbstring extension for PHP.

step.para: The whole install can take a long time, as everything will be downloaded and compiled on your machine. An install from scratch can easily take more than one hour.
Now install database support for PHP 5.3:
You can install MySQL and PostgreSQL (and other database) support by installing the relevant packages, e.g. php5-mysql or php5-postgresql.
Now activate the PHP in Apache.cd /opt/local/apache2/modules sudo /opt/local/apache2/bin/apxs -a -e -n "php5" libphp5.so

Now you need to assign the php file extension with the PHP interpreter. For this edit /opt/local/apache2/conf/httpd.conf and add AddType application/x-httpd-php .php inside the <IfModule mime_module> block.
Create a little test script with echo '<?php phpinfo(); ?>' > /opt/local/apache2/htdocs/phpinfo.php
Now you can start Apache with sudo /opt/local/etc/LaunchDaemons/org.macports.apache2/apache2.wrapper start
Call http://localhost/phpinfo.php and check if you have PHP 5.3 up and running.

section.title: Installation on Windows (based on XAMPP)
section.para: Go to http://www.apachefriends.org/. Download XAMPP for Windows (version 1.7.2 or higher) and install it.
You're done.

All PHP extensions and settings needed for FLOW3 are already done in the current XAMPP version. If you use another Apache/PHP framework you might find some useful hints how to set it up for FLOW3 in the next section.

section.title: Installation on Windows (based on an older XAMPP-version with PHP 5.2.x)
section.para: If you have some XAMPP older version with PHP 5.2.x running on your system and for some reason you don't want to upgrade to the current version, you can additionally install PHP 5.3 on port 81 for example. This part describes how to do that. We assume that you have installed XAMPP in the folder C:\xampp\.

section.title: Download and unzip PHP 5.3
section.para: Download the windows binaries. You need the file php-5.3.0-Win32-VC6-x86.zip (PHP 5.3 - Windows VC6 x86 (thread safe)) from the "windows-binaries-download-page": http://windows.php.net/download/#php-5.3-ts-VC6-x86.
Add the folder C:\xampp\php\php5.3. Extract the content of the ZIP file into this new folder.

section.title: Apache Configuration
section.para: Later you will start another apache process that should have its own configuration and its own log files.
So, what you do first, is

Copy the folder C:\xampp\apache\conf\ to C:\xampp\apache\conf-php5.3\
Create a new folder C:\xampp\apache\logs-php5.3\
Now change the files the new folder conf-php5.3.0\:

listitem.para: Change the port from 80 to 81: Listen 81
Adjust the includes of the configuration files: Search for conf/ and replace it with conf-php5.3/
Adjust the log file directory: Search for logs/ and replace it with logs-php5.3/
Add the configuration for using another PidFile (otherwise you might get some more entries in the error-log) by adding the following line. A good place is below ServerRoot:
Activate the module mod_rewrite by uncommenting the line (this might not be needed anymore in newer versions of XAMPP):LoadModule rewrite_module modules/mod_rewrite.so

section.para: Change the SSL-Port: Listen 4343
Here you tell the apache which .dll-files it should use as PHP-module.

listitem.para:
Add the following lines:#php5.3 settings: #Preload the PHP interpreter dll so that apache can find it, even if it's not in the path LoadFile "C:/xampp/php/php5.3/php5ts.dll"
#Load the sapi module for Apache LoadModule php5_module "C:/xampp/php/php5.3/php5apache2_2.dll"
#Specify the directory that the php.ini is stored in PHPIniDir "C:/xampp/php/php5.3"

section.para: Configure the VirtualHosts. Make them reference to the Web folder of your FLOW3 installation. You might want to add an additional VirtualHost for the Development Context of FLOW3 already.
section.screen:
NameVirtualHost *:81
<VirtualHost *:81> DocumentRoot "C:/xampp/htdocs/" ServerName localhost </VirtualHost>
<VirtualHost *:81> DocumentRoot "C:/xampp/htdocs/flow3/Web/" ServerName flow3.local </VirtualHost>
<VirtualHost *:81> DocumentRoot "C:/xampp/htdocs/flow3/Web/" ServerName dev.flow3.local SetEnv FLOW3_CONTEXT Development </VirtualHost>

note.para: For other virtual hosts than "localhost" you'll need an additional entry in your hosts-file. Open the file C:\windows\system32\drivers\etc\hosts and add the line 127.0.0.1 flow3.local dev.flow3.local.

section.title: Problems?
section.para: If you have problems starting the apache, there are two places that mostly help solving them:

listitem.para: Check the error log of the apache. (Did you choose the right log file? You should see the start of the apache in there.)
Have a look at the events in the Windows control panel. Usually you find more detailed information here than in the error log, if the apache crashed.

section.title: Installation on Windows 7 with IIS7
section.para: This part is still a draft somehow, because FLOW3 is running with IIS, but the steps to get it up and running are written down from memory only. Another point is, that these instructions are written based on a german windows version. That means that the translation of what you have to click at might be wrong sometimes. So please be patient, if you are missing something and open an issue on that on forge.
This is based on Windows 7 Ultimate and IIS7. You won't be able to do the same things on Windows XP as you can't install IIS7 there. But Windows Vista might work in a similar way.
Depending on your user access control settings you will be asked several times wether you want to allow doing things during the installation proccess.

step.para: Install PHP using the Web Plattform Installer (WPI). You can download it at http://www.microsoft.com/web/Downloads/platform.aspx.

Choose Web Platform on the left and check the checkbox for PHP inside the Frameworks and Runtime section on the right. It's a 5.2.x version of PHP, but doing it like this has the advantage that the WPI will take care of all dependencies PHP needs, which will make installing PHP 5.3 easier later on.
Go to the Webserver section and also check the checkbox at URL Rewrite (part of the Common HTTP Features).
Install.
Now you should see the IIS start screen calling http://localhost/ from your browser.
Download PHP 5.3 (.zip-file) from http://windows.php.net/download/. Choose the VC9 and non thread save version. Unzip it to C:\Program Files (x86)\PHP5.3.
Start the IIS-Manager by typing inetmgr into the quickstart input field (which opens after typing the windows key).

Add a handler for PHP 5.3: Klick on the root on the left (which is your computername probably) in the IIS-Manager and doubleklick on the button handlermapping on the right. Here you'll see a handler PHP_via_FastCGI already. Add handler PHP5.3_via_FastCGI using the same settings with one difference: The executable file must be set to C:\Program Files (x86)\PHP5.3\php-cgi.exe. Doing this you will be asked, if some FastCGI-application should be added. Confirm this.
No you can remove the "old" PHP Handler from the Websites you want to use with PHP 5.3.
Click on the root again (on the left) and choose the FastCGI settings. You have to add the environment variable PHPRC to the PHP5.3 settings. Do this similar to the PHP settings.
Configure php.ini: copy C:\Program Files (x86)\PHP5.3\php.ini-development to C:\Program Files (x86)\PHP5.3\php.ini and add/change this settings:

listitem.para: some settings you might want to look at are:
listitem.screen: fastcgi.impersonate = 1 cgi.fix_pathinfo = 1 cgi.force_redirect = 0 allow_url_fopen = Off allow_url_include = Off fastcgi.logging = 0

step.para: You have to restart the Default Web Site in the IIS-Manager to make the new settings having an effect.
Download FLOW3 and unzip it to the folder C:\inetpub\wwwroot\. We assume you put it into a subfolder flow3\, as you might want to have more than one flow3 installation.

Go back to the IIS Manager and add a new Website inside Sites. Choose C:\inetpub\wwwroot\flow3\Web as physical path and add some hostname like flow3.local. You need an entry for that host in the hosts file (C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts): 127.0.0.1 flow3.local.

Import the rewrite Rules from the .htaccess-file: Click on your new Site in the IIS-Manager (on the left). Doubleklick on URL Rewrite on the right. Click on import rule.... Choose the .htaccess file from the Web diroctory of your FLOW3 installation and say Import. Remove the line from the .htaccess rules that causes the error (it's about symlinks, not needed for windows) and apply (in the top right corner). Two rules have been added.
Restart the Site to make sure that the php.ini changes have an effect.
